items.title: Virus Striker
items.shortDesc: A DirectX 9-based action puzzle game submitted to the 2021 Regional Skills Competition

details.description: An action puzzle game in the style of Qix, reminiscent of the arcade classic 'Gals Panic.' Based on the theme 'Eradicate the Virus!', players control a Vaccine Injection Machine (VIM) to treat infected tissue. The core mechanism uses a FloodFill algorithm where players must fill a certain percentage of the map to clear the stage, avoiding pathogens that increase in difficulty over time.

specs.role: Responsible for DirectX 9 framework and core game system development

keyFeatures: Designed and implemented a 2D rendering engine framework based on DirectX 9
Implemented foundational game engine systems: Animation, Box/Circle Collision, Sound
Implemented texture masking using 2D array data to distinguish infected and treated areas
Implemented FloodFill algorithm for area clearing based on 2D array data
Developed a system to parse A-Z, 0-9 sprite sheets to output text without external fonts
Implemented ranking data I/O system via txt files
details.review: 'Virus Striker' was the first game I created while learning C and C++ in high school. This project is more than just a competition entry; it was my gateway into the world of game development. By handling everything from 2D rendering to collision and animation using DirectX APIs, I gained a practical understanding of game frameworks and engines. This foundation was immensely helpful when I later moved to Unity. Looking back, it reflects my pure passion and challenging spirit at the time.

items.title: Corona Striker
items.shortDesc: A vertical-scrolling action shooter submitted to the 2022 Regional Skills Competition

details.description: A vertical-scrolling action shooter similar to Strikers 1945. Set inside a patient's body, the player controls a vaccine robot to fight viruses. It features a unique mechanic where players must manage both the robot's health and the patient's pain gauge simultaneously.
keyFeatures: Implemented skills (Charge Shot) using Bezier Curves
Developed seamless background scrolling using alternating tiles
Configured monster patterns through 2D array data editable in the Unity Inspector
Implemented hit detection and item acquisition logic using Collision handling
details.review: This was my first Unity project after learning DirectX. My prior experience with graphic APIs greatly helped in understanding how Unity works under the hood. While I reused assets due to the competition's prompt being similar to my previous work, I felt some lack of detail in certain areas. Looking at the code now, I see many points for improvement in terms of design and hardcoding, making it a project I'd like to remaster someday.

items.title: Samchuk Adventure
items.shortDesc: A side-scrolling platformer created with Unity for a school performance assessment

details.description: A classic 2D side-scrolling action-adventure game. Players explore forests, dungeons, and caves, utilizing various combat styles including swords, spears, bows, and dodge rolls. It includes growth elements like equipment enhancement and shops, leading to a final boss fight and ending.

specs.role: Responsible for Graphics Pipeline, game mechanics implementation, and internal tool support

keyFeatures: Implemented a system to swap Animators at runtime based on the equipped weapon
Utilized URP 2D Light features for atmospheric thematic lighting
Implemented camera movement using Cinemachine
Developed equipment enhancement, shop, and dialogue UI using UGUI
Applied Rule Tiles and Gizmos to enhance efficiency in level design
details.review: This project marked my transition from the Built-in pipeline to URP. Despite initial hurdles like 'pink texture' bugs, the visual improvement was highly rewarding. It was also my first time collaborating with non-programmers, where I took the lead in schedule management and role distribution. Our project was recognized as the highest quality among the competing teams, and the experience of applying new features in a short timeframe was invaluable.

items.title: LowPoly Battlefield
items.shortDesc: A Low-poly FPS project focused on building 3D development knowledge

details.description: A learning-oriented project to master 3D systems. Focused on customizing external animation assets and exploring Animation Rigging, Animation Curves, and other 3D-specific functionalities.
keyFeatures: Implemented gun firing effects using the Particle System
Developed surface-dependent footstep sounds detected via Raycasting
Implemented reverb and soundproofing effects based on the environment
Developed a JSON-based I/O system for saving customizations
details.review: Although it ended at the prototype stage due to technical hurdles in complex 3D mechanics and asset optimization, it was a period of significant growth. I delved deep into IK-based animation correction and FPS fundamentals, which significantly increased my 3D system comprehension.

items.title: Twin Travelers
items.shortDesc: A 2D co-op puzzle platformer remaster of the 2022 National Skills Competition entry

details.description: A co-op puzzle platformer similar to Fireboy & Watergirl. Players use mechanics like keys, levers, and gravity portals to clear 50 stages. Supports both a single-player mode (controlling two characters) and real-time network co-op.
keyFeatures: Implemented lag compensation by inheriting Photon PUN2's IPunObservable interface
Developed multiplayer features using Photon PUN2 RPCs and Callbacks
Managed active sound effects using Object Pooling
Managed BGM/SFX lists as Dictionaries using ScriptableObjects
Implemented HDR and Outline effects using Shader Graph
Enhanced level design efficiency using Rule Tiles and Gizmos
details.review: This was my most ambitious project, reflecting my renewed passion for game development. Successfully implementing a multiplayer system with Photon PUN2 was a personal milestone, especially after struggling with various networking solutions in previous attempts. Moving forward, I plan to incorporate UniTask and UniRx for even better event-driven performance.

items.title: Sokoland
items.shortDesc: A 3D reimagining of the classic Sokoban puzzle platformer

details.description: A 3D puzzle platformer based on Sokoban mechanics. Players use portals, ladders, and camera rotations to place boxes in designated spots. The game is designed to challenge spatial awareness through varying themes and complex camera-dependent puzzles.

specs.role: Client Development, Level Design, Code Convention/Doc-style setup, and Project Management

keyFeatures: Implemented player movement and Game Over logic via UniTask and UniRx (Event-driven/Async)
Developed a structured data flow: Theme Data → Level Data → Save Data
Performed per-scene optimization and lighting (Static Batching / Baked Lighting)
Implemented camera rotation using Cinemachine
Developed custom editor scripts for auto-header insertion and per-camera screenshots
details.review: A great experience exploring collaboration tools and advanced Unity features. Managing version control via GitHub and overseeing the development workflow taught me what is truly required for professional teamwork. Successfully navigating the 'pain of creation' in level design while maintaining the schedule was a rewarding challenge.
